case_vignette: A healthy 30-year-old man presents with a 3-year history of an asymptomatic, fleshy papule at the base of his great toe. He denies any new lesions during this time, a history of trauma to the area, or a family history of similar skin lesions. He was treated previously by another dermatologist with cryotherapy; however, he returns to the clinic with recurrence of the lesion. Examination reveals a pedunculated, flesh-colored, well-demarcated tumor on the plantar surface of the base of his great toe.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have this small, flesh-like bump on the bottom part of my big toe, but it doesn't hurt or bother me.
How long have you had the bump on your toe?
I've had the bump for about 3 years.
Has the bump changed in size, color, or shape since you first noticed it?
No, the bump hasn't changed in size, color, or shape since I first noticed it.
Do you have any history of similar skin issues anywhere else on your body?
No, I haven't had any similar skin issues elsewhere on my body.
Have you had any recent injuries to your foot or changes in your physical activity?
No, I haven't had any injuries to the area or changes in my physical activity.
Do you have any pain or difficulty when walking or wearing shoes?
No, I don't have any pain or trouble walking or wearing shoes.
Is there a family history of skin conditions, or is anyone in your family known to have similar bumps?
No, there's no family history of similar skin conditions or bumps.
Final Diagnosis: Plantar fibroma
